title: Buenas noticias para las personas que buscan empleo: las ofertas de trabajo incluirÃ¡n esto en 2024
text:
La
UniÃ³n Europea ha hecho caso a los trabajadores y por fin obligarÃ¡ a las empresas a incluir en las ofertas de empleo algo que todos demandaban. Cuando entramos en un proceso de selecciÃ³n, queremos conocer todos los detalles posibles antes de tomar la decisiÃ³n final sobre el puesto. Entre todos los aspectos que se suelen destacar siempre hay uno que echamos en falta y que es vital para decidir si nos decantamos por elegir ese lugar de trabajo. Desde bruselas se quiere ayudar a los solicitantes de empleo a poner este requisito en todos los procesos de selecciÃ³n.
La medida afectarÃ¡ directamente a todas las sociedades que operan en alguno de los 27 paÃ­ses miembros de la UE y su plazo de transiciÃ³n para su aplicaciÃ³n durarÃ¡ hasta junio de 2026. A partir de esa fecha, todos los que oferten un trabajo deberÃ¡n poner al detalle todos los pormenores del contrato, incluido esto que siempre es lo mÃ¡s polÃ©mico. Los trabajadores aplauden esta decisiÃ³n, porque la mayorÃ­a de interesados consideran este aspecto esencial antes de inscribirse en una oferta. SegÃºn el portal Infojobs, 9 de cada 10 personas considera que este requisito debe estar incluido en las ofertas de empleo.
Hasta junio de 2026 no serÃ¡ obligatorio seÃ±alar este apartado que muchos piden, pero sÃ­ es recomendable para las empresas que empiecen a incluirlo, al menos, en los procesos de selecciÃ³n y las entrevistas. De esta manera, la UE quiere avanzar hacia la transparencia total en estos trÃ¡mites que son tan importantes para las personas que quieren acceder a un puesto de trabajo.
Conoce cuÃ¡nto cobrarÃ¡s antes de la decisiÃ³n final
La UniÃ³n Europea aprobÃ³ en mayo de este aÃ±o Ley de Transparencia Salarial por la que todas las empresas estarÃ¡n obligadas a incluir el salario que cobrarÃ¡ la persona que finalmente se haga con ese puesto de trabajo. A pesar de que la Directiva de la UniÃ³n Europea 2023/970 entrÃ³ en vigencia hace unos meses, no serÃ¡ hasta el 7 de junio de 2026 cuando todos los gobiernos tengan que cumplir con esta exigencia. Durante este plazo de transposiciÃ³n obligatorio, las organizaciones tendrÃ¡n que acatar la normativa que serÃ¡ aplicable a:
- Todos los trabajadores que tengan contrato de trabajo o relaciÃ³n laboral.
- Las personas que soliciten empleo.
- Los empleados de los sectores pÃºblicos y privados.
La UE quiere reforzar el principio de igualdad de salarios por un mismo trabajo entre hombres y mujeres y asÃ­ prohibir la brecha salarial por gÃ©nero. SegÃºn satos de la propia UniÃ³n Europea, en el aÃ±o 2020, los hombres ganaban un 13% mÃ¡s que las mujeres por realizar el mismo empleo. Esta
desigualdad salarial es uno de los objetivos que quieren reducir desde Bruselas. AdemÃ¡s, el Consejo tambiÃ©n piensa que poner el sueldo en la oferta de trabajo favorecerÃ¡ competencia entre empresas y contribuirÃ¡ en que los interesados puedan ganar mÃ¡s dinero.
Los trabajadores estÃ¡n contentos
La mayorÃ­a de personas que buscan un empleo confiesan que el salario es uno de los puntos clave antes de dar el paso hacia ese empleo, sin embargo, no es el Ãºnico. Las condiciones laborales, las horas que trabajarÃ¡s, el lugar donde se encuentra la empresa o los compaÃ±eros tambiÃ©n influyen en esta decisiÃ³n. Estos datos deben ser razonables y creÃ­bles, y siempre de acuerdo con el perfil del puesto.
Infojobs ha realizado una encuesta a sus usuarios en la que 9 de cada 10 suscritos apoyan que esta ley se lleve a cabo. Es vital que las empresas muestren transparencia en estos procesos, ya que la mitad de los encuestados consideran que este aspecto tambiÃ©n es importante para confiar en ese trabajo.

title: Should parents buy school supplies for the entire class? TikTok is divided
text:
â€œCommunalâ€ school supply lists are rattling parents on TikTok, with some asking, â€œWhy should I buy scissors and highlighters for other children?â€
For many families, back-to-school shopping includes notebooks, markers and folders, not just for their kids but for their peers as well. While certain states require schools to provide basic supplies, classroom budgets are tight. To ensure that all children have enough supplies â€” weâ€™ve seen how kids treat pencils, right? â€” teachers often have two options: pay for a portion of supplies themselves, usually without reimbursement , or create â€œwish listsâ€ requesting families to contribute bulk items once or twice a year.
If youâ€™re asked to buy two dozen glue sticks, itâ€™s either because teachers expect your child to use every single one this year or they benefit students whose families canâ€™t afford to buy supplies. Extras are also handy when items go missing or break. Teachers may ask parents to buy specific brands or basic, nondescript supplies without branding or flourishes. Sometimes teachers request bigger items, too, like whiteboard markers, disinfecting wipes and tissues.
Each teacher has their own system but most agree that no one wants to snatch Billyâ€™s favorite Spider-Man eraser and give it to his mortal enemy. While specific guidelines vary by classroom, the purpose of general supplies is that they all look the same and are there for the taking as needed.
Some parents contribute, others cannot. And some have complicated feelings about the responsibility.
One mom on TikTok wrote, â€œI spent upwards of $400 on school stuff for seven kids a year. I am not buying for a whole classâ€ while another simply said, â€œSome parents donâ€™t like to share apparently.â€
Frances Chie, a mom in Ohio, wants to buy personalized supplies for her 3-year-old daughter who is entering preschool this year, but not necessarily her peers. While their school only asks families to buy supplies for their own children, Chie suspects that communal supplies are in her future.
â€œIf my baby wants Disney Princess pencils, a pencil case (and) erasers and I go and buy them, why wouldnâ€™t she be using them?â€ Chie said in a TikTok video.
@lovefranceschiee What are your thoughts? ðŸ¤” | #schoolsupplies #backtoschool #momsoftiktok #greenscreen
â™¬ original sound â€“ Love Frances Chie ðŸ’• Parents and teachers responded:
â€œI will label each crayon individually with my childâ€™s name, a whole 128 pack. I donâ€™t care.â€ â€œWhat I buy for my children is THEIRS. And I will be telling their teachers the same.â€ â€œAs a teacher, I understand this but also, we have to pay for so much of it.â€ â€œFirst grade teacher here. The only supplies I use as community supplies are pencils and glue sticks, only because they need help managing supplies at this age. They will need 24 pencils, just not on Day One.â€ â€œI donâ€™t think most parents understand how much little kids lose or break pencils and crayons.â€ â€œTeachers have to handle 18 to 25 children. Please just do whatever your teacher wants you to do.â€ Chie tells TODAY.com that she and her daughter are excited to find supplies branded with Disney, Bluey and unicorns.
â€œIf parents are going school shopping with their little ones, and picking out things that (reflect) their special interests â€¦ those kids should use those supplies,â€ she says.
Chie says she was surprised to learn that many teachers pay for classroom decorations and supplies with their own money and she would be happy to donate more communal items, like paper towels, hand sanitizer and tissues to the classroom, but draws the line at more personal items.
Sarah Spikeston, a Texas mom and community college professor, is in favor of communal school supplies. (@sarahspikeston via TikTok) Sarah Spikeston of Texas pays a flat fee to her daughterâ€™s private school to purchase communal supplies while her sonâ€™s private Montessori preschool allows for both personal and shared items.
â€œAs someone who was chronically poor growing up and homeless for parts of (my youth), meeting the needs of all kids, regardless of their circumstances, is really important to me,â€ Spikeston, a community college professor in Texas, tells TODAY.com via email.
She adds: â€œI know what itâ€™s like to be the kid thatâ€™s left without and that classrooms run more efficiently when they are fully stocked and thereâ€™s some level of uniformity in supplies.â€
Spikeston says some parents dislike buying generic brands but kids donâ€™t care about sharing supplies, especially when theyâ€™re expressing their individuality elsewhere.
â€œWe have to remember that any of us could begin to struggle in the blink of an eye,â€ says Spikeston. â€œThose of us that are blessed to be able to afford school supplies have a duty to the community because the community in turn funds our public schools.â€
Todd Bloch, a middle school science teacher in Michigan, understands that supplies are expensive and that families may have brand favorites or want to label their childrenâ€™s supplies.
Supply lists are a â€œbalancing actâ€ for teachers, too.
â€œItâ€™s difficult to know exactly what we need going into the school year, especially when store sales usually happen in June,â€ Bloch tells TODAY.com.
When parents can afford to buy supplies, says Bloch, it saves teachers from diving into their classroom budgets so they can spend that money elsewhere â€” like baking soda and vinegar to demonstrate chemical reactions with a â€œcoolâ€ fizz, he says.
With experience, Bloch has fine-tuned his supply list: kids trace perfect circles using cheap paper coffee cups instead of compasses, technological information can be stored in the cloud versus flash drives, and standard pencils trump refillable mechanical tools. When Blochâ€™s students built solar ovens with aluminum foil and cardboard, they brought in their familyâ€™s used pizza boxes. It helps that Blochâ€™s school reimburses him a portion of what he spends. If Bloch wants to do something special, like reward his students with Jolly Ranchers, he pays out of his own pocket.
Bloch communicates his recommendations for supplies to parents and reassures students they will be fully prepared, one way or another.
â€œTeachers just want to create an equitable experience for students,â€ says Bloch. â€œIf parents canâ€™t help make that happen, most teachers totally understand.â€

author: MENAFN
title: Need To Find More Solutions Amongst Ourselves, EAM Jaishankar Tells Bay Of Bengal Nations
text: New Delhi, July 11 (IANS) Asserting that longstanding goals such as capacity building and economic cooperation have acquired a new urgency, External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar on Thursday called for deepening and broadening of activities between the Bay of Bengal countries. "Global and regional developments also make it imperative that we find more solutions amongst ourselves," he said in his opening remarks at the two-day 2nd BIMSTEC Foreign Ministers' Retreat which began in New Delhi. "For India, BIMSTEC (Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation) represents the interaction of the 'Neighbourhood First' outlook, the 'Act East' policy and the SAGAR vision. Each of these endeavours is being purposed with a specific focus on the Bay of Bengal by the collaborative potential that has long remained under-realised. Our challenge is to change that for the better and to do so rapidly," he stated. The EAM is hosting his counterparts for the significant meet which brings together seven countries of South and South East Asia for multifaceted cooperation. "The Retreat will present an opportunity for the Foreign Ministers of the BIMSTEC countries to discuss, in an informal setting, avenues to broaden and deepen cooperation across various sectors including in the fields of security, connectivity, trade and investment, people to people contacts etc, in the Bay of Bengal region and littoral," the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) said in a statement. The first edition of the BIMSTEC Foreign Ministers' Retreat was held in Bangkok in July 2023 as India continues to reiterate its commitment to promote connectivity and linkages in the shared Bay of Bengal region. Bangladesh Foreign Minister Hasan Mahmud, Thailand Foreign Minister Maris Sangiampongsa (current BIMSTEC chair), Bhutan Foreign Minister D.N. Dhungyel, Nepal Foreign Secretary Sewa Lamsal and Myanmar's Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister U Than Swe and State Minister of Foreign Affairs of Sri Lanka Tharaka Balasuriya are attending the meeting which is expected to bolster regional cooperation. Last month, as he congratulated Prime Minister Narendra Modi on the BJP-led NDA's third consecutive term, Thailand Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin said that he is already looking forward to the Indian leader's visit to the country in September this year for the BIMSTEC Summit. "While Prime Minister Modi will be visiting Thailand in September this year to attend the BIMSTEC Summit; on my part, I look forward to paying an official visit to India at the earliest opportunity to realise the full potential of our relations," said Thavisin. Die Wahrheit Ã¼ber Burnout, die viele nicht hÃ¶ren wollen
Burnout und chronische ErschÃ¶pfung nehmen immer weiter zu. Eine Expertin erklÃ¤rt, warum so viele im Job leiden und das PhÃ¤nomen Ã¼berhaupt existiert.
Wer im Job nur noch zynische Kommentare von sich gibt, nichts mehr auf die Reihe bekommt und beim Gedanken an den nÃ¤chsten Montag nicht schlafen kann, hat vermutlich ein Burnout. So wie immer mehr Deutsche: Laut AOK-Daten hat sich die Anzahl der ArbeitsunfÃ¤higkeitsfÃ¤lle durch Burnout von 2014 auf 2023 um 50 Prozent erhÃ¶ht.
Hochgerechnet auf die Gesamtzahl von 35 Millionen gesetzlich Versicherten waren damit 2023 etwa 186.000 Menschen mit insgesamt 4,7 Millionen Fehltagen wegen eines Burnouts krankgeschrieben. 61 Prozent der Deutschen befÃ¼rchten laut einer Studie der Betriebskrankenkasse Pronova, an einem Burnout zu erkranken. Elf Prozent mehr als noch vor sechs Jahren.
â€žDie Burnout-Statistiken sind in letzter Zeit dramatisch in die HÃ¶he geschossenâ€œ, sagt Anna Katharina Schaffner BuzzFeed News Deutschland von IPPEN.MEDIA. Die Burnout-Expertin und Kulturhistorikerin hat mehrere BÃ¼cher Ã¼ber das PhÃ¤nomen geschrieben, 2024 erschien ihr Buch â€žErschÃ¶pft? Belebende Perspektiven fÃ¼r mÃ¼de Menschenâ€œ.
Burnout von der WHO nicht als psychisches Leiden definiert â€“ Expertin sieht â€žParadoxâ€œ
In Deutschland wird ein Burnout nicht als Krankheit, sondern als Zustand physischer und psychischer ErschÃ¶pfung definiert. Er wird unter der Diagnosegruppe Z73 â€žProbleme mit Bezug auf Schwierigkeiten bei der LebensbewÃ¤ltigungâ€œ zusammengefasst, orientiert sich an der alten Richtlinie ICD-10, die von der WHO schon lÃ¤ngst weiterentwickelt wurde. Manche Psychiater kritisieren immer noch, dass â€žBurnoutâ€œ eine Modediagnose sei, um das Wort â€žDepressionâ€œ (laut WHO eine psychische StÃ¶rung) nicht benutzen zu mÃ¼ssen.*
Schaffner sieht das anders: â€žEin Burnout ist das direkte Resultat von chronischem Arbeitsstressâ€œ und unterscheide sich ganz deutlich von Depression und anderen Lebenskrisen, sagt sie BuzzFeed News Deutschland. Dass die Weltgesundheitsorganisation (WHO) es als â€žberuflich bedingte Erkrankung und nicht als psychisches Leidenâ€œ definiere, bezeichnet sie als â€žBurnout-Paradoxâ€œ. Denn damit werde Betroffenen suggeriert, dass sie nicht â€žerfolgreich genugâ€œ mit chronischem Stress im Job umgingen, wo sie sich frage, wie das Ã¼berhaupt aussehen solle.
Die Strukturen der Arbeitswelt wÃ¼rden es Einzelpersonen sehr schwer machen, etwas gegen die ErschÃ¶pfung im Job zu unternehmen. FÃ¼r viele sei das Ausgebrannt-sein trotzdem mit Scham und SchuldgefÃ¼hlen besetzt. Doch die Wahrheit sei, dass â€žein Burnout auf jeden Fall nicht nur ein individualpsychologisches Problem ist, sondern ganz klar eine sozial-kulturelle Dimension hat, weil wir Arbeitswelten geschaffen haben, die extrem toxisch und schÃ¤dlich sind fÃ¼r unsere Psychenâ€œ, sagt Schaffner.
Warum Burnout als Diagnose-Begriff â€žextrem wichtigâ€œ ist
Laut der Burnout-Expertin gibt es in der â€žArbeitswelt des 21. Jahrhunderts ganz spezifische psychosoziale und Ã¶konomische Stressfaktoren. Viele davon sind heimtÃ¼ckischâ€œ, sagt sie. Zum Beispiel das Konkurrenzdenken im Job, der Wachstumszwang und die stÃ¤ndige Gewinnmaximierung in Unternehmen. Technologie wie Social Media erleichterten zwar die Kommunikation, mache uns jedoch auch abhÃ¤ngig, denn â€ždurch die stÃ¤ndige Erreichbarkeit kÃ¶nnen wir dem, was uns stresst, kaum mehr entkommenâ€œ.
Wegen all dieser Dinge litten immer mehr Menschen an chronischen ErschÃ¶pfungszustÃ¤nden und nicht etwa, weil Burnout eine â€žModediagnoseâ€œ sei. â€žImmer mehr Menschen leiden auf der Arbeit und an der Arbeit; immer mehr Menschen finden es extrem schwierig, Arbeitsthemen am Abend loszulassen; immer mehr Menschen schaffen es nicht mehr, eine gute Work-Life-Balance aufrechtzuerhalten.â€œ
Hinzu kÃ¤me, dass die Gesellschaft mehr und offener Ã¼ber Burnouts spreche. Auch die Ã¶konomische Unsicherheit, die Bedrohung durch den Klimawandel sowie Kriege und die Pandemie wÃ¼rden sich auf die Burnout-Zahlen auswirken: â€žWenngleich auch unsere Vorfahren mit ErschÃ¶pfung zu kÃ¤mpfen hatten, besteht kein Zweifel, dass wir in Zeiten besonders raschen Wandels mit besonders komplexen und beunruhigenden Problemen leben.â€œ
Schaffner findet es â€žextrem wichtigâ€œ, dass wir â€žBurnoutâ€œ als Diagnose-Begriff nutzen. â€žWir mÃ¼ssen verstehen, dass wir mit unserem Leiden an und auf der Arbeit nicht alleine sind. Dass es dafÃ¼r klare strukturelle, gesellschaftliche und technologische GrÃ¼nde gibtâ€œ, sagt sie. â€žEs ist wichtig, Burnout nicht nur durch die individualpsychologische Linse zu sehen, sondern auch als ein ernstes strukturelles Problem unserer Zeit.â€œ
*In einer vorherigen Version haben wir nicht erwÃ¤hnt, dass die Richtlinie ICD-10 zum Burnout, an der sich Deutschland orientiert, veraltet ist. Wir haben die betreffende Stelle korrigiert.
